element_texts.text:
Chapter XI
Surveying Incidents, continued-Job Stickney? or There's Many a Slip between the Cup and the Lip.
Saturday, Sept. 21st.-Surveyed another Island.  The 22d being Sunday remained in camp.  The 23d and 24th and 25th were occupied in finishing up the Islands, and on the 26 removed camp to Squirrel Grove against a very strong head wind.  High wind and a severe rain prevailed on the 27th, which gave us a complete drenching.  The 28 was very pleasant, with a fresh breeze from the North West.
Monday, 30th.-Removed camp to within four miles of Saginaw River.  Passed Bear river, which is twenty yards wide and twelve feet deep at its mouth.  Its course is principally through low, wet prairies.
Wednesday, Oct 1st.-In consequence of a thunder storm, yesterday and today were spent in our tents listening to the yarns of the men.  One of which is good enough to be repeated.
Job Stickney? was a man of universal genius and such an one as can be born and brought up only in Yankeedom.  There was nothing that he could not do-from whittling out a toothpick with his jack-knife to building a house with a broad axe and handsaw.  His favorite saying was, "That the world owed him a living, and he would have it some how or other;" and he lived up to his phi-

of all my sins in as little about the quickest thrice, and wish myself to hum agin, then I didn't, that's all.  I was hauled a board, howsoever, and soon on the road to mine-I mean York-but its sin-on-unclear, I guess.
'I had never been aboard on a steamboat before, and so soon as I was dry, I went pryin' about and peekin' into one place and another, to see what I could find out in her fixin's and gearin's to speculate on.  The hands on the boat soon found out that I was green 'un.  In the boiler room I got my face well smouched?; the cooks pinned a dish cloth to my back-the porters and hands knocked me about as so much lumber-the bar-keeper treat me to rum and salt-I got a jet of steam in my face while investigatin' the mysteries of the engine room, and was knocked down by a surly old unclear for lookin' over his shoulder to see what he was writin' about.  The wind blew pretty considerable on the Sound, and I was pesky sick; so I was considerably elevated when the boat touched the wharf in York, and hastened ashore-but I was again too fast in my calculations, for in jumpin' I lit right under a basket of eggs an old woman had gist deposited on the deck.
"Gist pay me for them are eggs," says she.
"I haint go no money," says I; and I started off under a sun.  She cried out, and the people on the dock cried out, and the men on the

losophy, although with no very marked success, as will be seen.  But I will let him tell his own story, without any of the usual flourishes of an authors imagination.
'I was born,' said he, 'in the town of Danbury, Connecticut-brought up under tight reins, and when I was of age, away I went, to seek my fortin in the world alone-not even stoppin' to bid a fond mother good-bye, or receive and blessin' from a good old father.  Ever since that time I have been there tumbled about in the lap of fortin', sometimes with one side up, and sometimes with to'ther, but always finding myself thar' in the end.  You have hearn say that "there is many a slip between the cup and the lip;" and that's just what I have experienced all my life-never mind, there is some fun in this life yet and I'll shake it out.  Well, the first thing I did after vamousin' was to steer right for New Haven, where I visited about all the shops and stores in the place for a situation, without success, bein' told in more nor one that they had gist got a clerk.  Well, thinks I, I'll go to York; and as it was near upon the time for the boat to start, I streaked it for the wharf, and ariv' gist as she was swingin' off.  I give a spring, and, unclear I went into the briney deep.  I didn't know how to swim, and came as near "uncoiling this mortal shiffle," as Shakespeare says, as I want to for a spell, and I tell you what, of I didn't think

was follerin' their example-I became desperate and took liberties with other people's property.  I didn't like the game, no hers, but the world owes man a livin', and if he can't git it honestly, why he must git it.  (A very foolish retribe?).  Byne by I cam across a well dressed feller who wanted help, he said, and asked me if I could write.
"Oh! yes, says I, "I've been to schull, and through college too!"
"That's right.  But you don't look as if you had ever seen the inside of a college," says he, peekin' through my gosamer hat, and inter my goos? deer coat.
"Well, you see," say I, to explain, "I was desperate hard up a spell ago, and went inter the back door of old Columbia to see what I could find with appropriating, when they kicked me out at the front door."
'Well, this chap wanted me to use my larnin' in counterfetin' notes, and offered strong indorsements, but I couldn't go that, no how, and oi parted.  I then worked my way to Albany, and got abroad on a canal boat-follered the business three years, and then fell in love with an unclear pretty gal in Roeme.  I sparked up to her considerable strong for a long spell, but some how or other I couldn't git the hang of the thing so as to come the sentimental.  She was an oprhan, and

boat cried out, and they all cried out- "Stop that vagabond!" but on I darted up the street.  Howsomever, I wasn't fast enough to escape the shower of broken eggs that was sent after me; and if I wasn't a little the most curious critter you ever did see, then my name's not Job Hickney.  Howsomever I then went ahead like a high-pressure locomotive, and as soon as I go tout of harm's way, I set about tidyin' myself up-but it was an awful job, I tell you.  As soon as it was done, I went right straight to work to get a place.  After lookin' about considerable, I at last found an old gentleman who was polite enough to ask me where my recommend was, as he wanted a porter.  Now, I hadn't no recommend, but I gist up with my hand an' strokin' down my face, "Here," says I.  He seemed kind of tickled with the answer, and said he'd give me a trial; so I off coat and went to work.  I stopped with him a spell, and saved some money, which I goin' to lay out for a farm at the west, when jist as I thought I had enough, and calculated to draw it from the bank where I had put it for safe keepin', the pesky thing busted up, and I lost it all.  My boss had all his money thar too, and he busted up, so I was jist thar agin and ready for a fresh start.  But I couldn't find nothing to do-was turned out of several boarding houses for not payin'- my toes stuck of my shoes-my elbers and knees

"Because I'm engaged to another," says she.  "I thought you didn't care about me, Job, as you never said you did and Tom Jones was so pressin'-and next to you I liked him best that I consented.  It isn't twenty minutes since I promised to be his wife tomorrow."
"Oh! so soon!" I cried; and givin' her one last fond look, I unclear out of the house.  The cup had again slipped from my lips.  I squared accounts with the unclear of the canal boat, and made tracks for Buffalo-shipped aboard of a schooner bound for Erie-was wrecked off Dunkirk, and got ashore with a bruised head and empty pockets, my money goin' to the bottom with the schooner.  I took my knife and went to work mekin' axe heloes?, picked up a few dollars, and set off afoot for Erie, payin' my way as I went by mendin' clocks, rakes, wheelbarrows, carts, threshin' machines, and doin' any other odd job that turned up.  There I made some money by hardwork as a chopper-didn't see why other folks should be gettin' rich faster nor I by speculation-took Mr. Prince's advice and trid my hand in the unclear unclear business, and in one month found myself gist back thar agin, ready for another fresh start.
'Next, I went to Toledo-driv the stage a spell for Woodworth and C; and again saved some money to buy a farm with-but the fever and na

had some money, and I thought she had a kind of snickerin' after me.  At last I made a desperate push and propounded the interrogatory.
"Job," says she, "you are a nice young man."  My heart began to go ker-chunk! ker-chunk! ker-chunk!  "And I don't know nobody I should like better for a husband."  I was in a perfect fever and unclear of happiness.  "You are a smart young man, and appear to be both industrious and prudent; and that's what every young woman of sense wants in a husband-except them as is brought up in the aristocracies"-my excitabilites had got up to the bilin' pint-"and I don't know anyone  I should like better-"
I threw myself upon my knees before her, turk her lily white hadn and smarked it smartly-but I couldn't account for the large tears that ran like a mill stream down her cheeks.  She wiped them off, and continued:

twelve to twenty two feet deep.  The fifth and sixth we were detained in camp by rain.  On the sixth surveyed the river although still stormy.
Tuesday 7th-During the day as yesterday.  In the evening I found a remarkably curious insect which emitted a most brilliant light.  It was about an inch long, and three tenths of an inch in circumference.  On each side was a row of nine beautiful shots of a yellow tinge from which it emitted its light.  Between these two rows, on the back were two stripes of a yellowish purple color, which alternated with three others of a brownish hue.
Wednesday, 8th-Passed the unclear river; which is about fifty yards in width and seven feet deep; and, unlike most of the rivers of the bay, has high banks at its mouth, possessing advantages for mills of the finest kind.  The land is covered with pine, fur and e.
Thursday, 9th  Remained in camp and took observations with unclear.  North latitude 95 17' 5" and distant from Port unclear 167 miles.
Friday 10th  Surveyed nearly all day through a marsh, and crossed Potatoe river two miles from the unclear.  Here we had a hearty laugh at the expanse of unclear P.  Being commandant of the expedition it would be natural to suppose, that a mind like his would-as he did-choose the least arduous part of the work, namely,

ger turk hold on me, shook all the teeth out of my mouth, the hair off my head, and the money out of my pockets.  As Toledo had made me a shaker, I made up my mind to go in for the Shakin'  unclear joined them at New Lebanon-had some fun with their peculiarities 'till I got well, and then vamoused-dove inter the woods of Indiana, and grubbed stumps-laid up fir hundred dollars, and then started for a land office-entered a quarter section, and looked around and purchased stock and tools-went back, built a house, and considered myself settled-had a fine crop of wheat growin', and then like a darned fool, sold out to an old chap, who tuck a fancy to my location, for three times morn it art me.  Thought I'd play the gentleman a spell before buyin' another farm-went to Chicago-got inter the hands of some men smarter than myself-was fleeced, and her I am jist thar agin, takin' another fresh start."
Job looked as if he could and would, take many more fresh starts before he got through the bored?.
Thursday, Oct 2nd-Surveyed through water, knee deep, to the camp.
Friday, 3rd-Struck our tents and steered for Saginaw? river, where we encamped at 12 o'clock m.  This the largest river emptying into Saginaw? Bay and one of the largest in Michigan.  It is from a quarter to half a mile wide for some miles above its mouth, and from

vinced that anything I could say to Lieut. P- would have no effect, I gave him advice, which I promised would be more effective.  He determined to try it, and I took care that both officers and men should have an inkling of what was to transpire.
It was not long before an opportunity offered.  Pototatoe river was more than ordinarily deep at the ford, and rather muddy.  We all, however,-except Lieut P-, strode in and waded across, leaving him in some astonishment at the presumption of Antonie-the Canadian-in crossing without rendering him the usual assistance.  In an angry tone he bid him, "come back and perform your duty."
Totteringly the poor fellow entered the water with his burden, and the Lieutenant feeling himself rather unsteady began to show strong symptoms of fear.  Just as they gained the centre, and deepest part of the stream, the Canadian for a moment swerved and then fell, head foremost into the turpid water, entirely disappearing for a moment and then rising, spluttering and blowing like a couple of porpoises.  I never saw a more ludicrous sight in my life than that presented by the pompous Lieutenant-as, with arms extended at an angle of about forty five degrees with the body, his head projected forward, the water streaming

removing camp and using the unclear, both of which required very little mental and no bodily exertion.  In performing the first he usually took particular delight in going so far ahead of the surveyers that they were often obliged-after their day's work was done-to walk or row several miles to the camp; and occasionally the men-worn out as they were-would be set to work chopping wood and building fires, of an enormous size, in front of his tent to keep off the mosquitoes.  Sometimes we would have to give up all idea of finding him and stretch ourselves without supper upon the damp ground and sleep, if we could.
Among the Canadians who formed the larger portions of the operatives was one of the gigantic proportions, but of a very mild disposition, making him a very ready and willing instrument in the hands of Lieut. P-, and appropriate to the duty assigned to him.  This was to carry the Lieutenant on his back over every fordable stream-  Every on else wading over, like men.  The frequent occurrence of this task made the Canadian, at last, the butt of his companions, every man of whom would have sooner abandoned the expedition, and thrown up their pay, than submit to such a dagradation.  After enduring their jeers as long as it was possible he came to me in hopes that I could in some way, relieve him, as I had before done for others of the party.  Con

Thursday, 16th-  Notwithstanding the severity of the weather and the caution of Capt. unclear Lieut. P- resolved to proceed.  The attempt to cross the bar at the mouth of the river proved abortive as the sea ran so high that the boats were soon filled and with much difficulty we succeeded in getting back.  Wind S.E.
Friday, 17th-  Wind continued to blow a gale, and snow fell in the afternoon in large flakes.  The wind changed on the 18th to the north and continued violent.  Amused ourselves with a game of ball.
Sunday, 19th-  The wind having abated in some measure we proceeded as far as point an Chene?, but unable to double it were obliged to land.
Monday, 20th - Proceeded homeward; wind high from the east.  Passed Point an unclear, Sugar Loaf Point and Pidgeon river and landed for the night two miles south of Point an Barque.  
The rest of the journey was boisterous and disagreeable without any thing worthy of note.
From the time of my return until the middle of January of the following year I devoted myself to looking after my mother's business.  Cousin Tom-roaring Tom-of unclear, paid us a New Year's visit and on his return I was induced to accompany him.  We traveled on horseback without any adventure worth recording, except that on the last night, with the thermometer 32 below zero, we came very near be

from his hair over his face, and his clothes adhering tightly to his long, lank person, he came gulping and puffing to the shore, looking as if he could eat a whole platoon by the way of relish?.  This one dose effectually cured him.
Sunday 12th.  Yesterday and to-day remained in camp.  Several canoe loads of Indians passed, on their way to Saginaw to receive the money annually paid to them by our government.  A strange scene usually takes place on these occasions.  After receiving his silver the Indian is met at the door by men, who are employed by different traders in Indian merchandize, who seize upon him and a tussel ensuse for possession of the money.  The trader whose agent is successful pockets the silver? and the Indian is obliged to purchase at his store.  Sometimes the Indian succeeds in escaping with his treasure; in which case he trades with whom he pleases.
Monday, 13.-  Removed camp six miles-and on the 14th finished the survey for the season at 9 o'clock A.M.  The rest of the day being rainy and boisterous all hands were occupied in getting ready for our homeward voyage.
Wednesday, 15th.-  Launched our boats at daybreak and by seven o'clock were under way.  Passed Point an Sable, unclear, Saginaw, Bear and Thread rivers and camped at Crooked river after a hard day's work.

ihood to labor through my pen impressions of human life - of this sketch, to deter you for a moment from prosecuting your unclear to a final capitulation, for the fortress of woman's affections is well worth all the ammunitions expended for its conquest, notwithstanding it sometimes blows up and scatters ruin around, or, like a cannon ball, goes off with a flash and buries itself in oblivion.  But I am forgetting my subject, and giving advice which may, per chance, resemble the powder and end in smoke.  So to my yarn.
In the village of K- all the lads and lassies were - as in all new country towns where they are not very numerous and where fashion had made no advance - on the most familiar terms.  There kisses did not go by favor, neither was a man turned out of doors and refused apple pie for supper for taking one whenever we could get an opportunity; neither was it a disgrace to sit when the knee of a beaux and join in a chorus from Watt's and Rippon, or in a duet on two lips.  Of course people who were so unsophisticated in these matters could hardly be expected to be otherwise in the little et ceteras appertaining to the etiquette of polished society, for heart and fashion cannot flourish upon the same stem.
Being the guest of a family the younger por?

ing frozen to death, or rather cousin Tom did, for I actually suffered very little, although less warmly clad.  This I have always considered was owing to the fact of my strictly temperate habits.  At every stage of our journey cousin Tom would regale himself with a stiff hot toddy which I took nothing but the coldest of water.  My kind old uncle and aunt E- and sweet cousins Ann and Mary received us with open arms and affectionate greeting, and during the fortnight I remained with them treated me like a prince.  Good, kind cousin Ann has been long an angel in heaven, and sweet, affectionate Mary is still I hope the loving wife of a loving husband.  While here two very amusing incidents occurred to which I will devote the next chapter.
Chapter XII
A Backwood's Wedding-The Speculator and His Victim
Ah!  does not that-'wedding'- recall a happy event of bye-gone days; or perhaps you have never enjoyed the blessed companionship of one of earth's brightest petals; but then you may be in expectation of one, and in that case, what a thrill of joyous rapture must be thine in the contemplation; but, harken! do not suffer the perusal- if you have the hard

trudge the whole distance on foot.  I shall not stop to describe how one of my fair charges lost a shoe in a mud hole, or how another mistook a large puddle that lay in our path for a dry piece of terra firma, and in springing into it lost her centre of gravity, and very composedly seated herself in the element; or how a third tore her ringlets out by running into a bramble bus, for they were "harem-scarem" girls and would do just as they pleased, notwithstanding my remonstrances, but let us go directly into the festive hall and "peruse" the joyous assembly of republicans.  We won't be too censorious, however, for that would be showing a want of politeness.
After going through the preliminaries of pulling off a pair of muddy overshoes with a fine pair of kid gloves, for fear of soiling a clean pair of hands, hanging up my hat and clock in the hall, and arranging every thing about the person in "apple-pie order," I was ushered - not exactly by an usher of the black rod, but of a black face, into a small room unclear crowded with guests bobbing up and down in a cotillion.  Having to pass through the middle of a set, I came very near being upset by the hoppers? in their "forwards" and "backs."  We had arrive late, and the ceremony had been performed so I lost, as I was informed, the most

tion of which was composed of the gentler sex, it necessarily became my duty, as it was my pleasure, to accompany them to all the merry makings that took place in the neighborhood; and as it was at that season of the year when the white mantel of Jack Frost lay pretty heavily upon the ground, I usually bundled them into a crockery crate fixed upon runners made of hickory poles - a species of carry all commonly denominated at the west a jumper' - and which answered a very good purpose in the absence of the legitimate sleigh; and even better, as I could give them an occasional tumble in a snow bank without fear of injury either to the vehicle or to their sweet little limbs; and I assure you I suffered no opportunity to present itself without indulging in this practical joke, it was such capital sport to see the gay creatures scramble up, and hear their merry peals of laughter at any little catastrophe that might occur during their efforts to regain their feet.  The young ladies of the village were not all, however, of the same sensible stamp as those whom it was my good fortune to gallant, as the sequel will show.
It was on a night very unlike those I have mentioned that I was invited to attend a wedding.  Owing to a "warm spell" the snow had disappeared, and a drenching rain during the day had made the roads impassable for any kind of vehicle and consequently we were obliged to

19
was Piper, you see - "don't ye pipe too long on that instrument, if you please; he! he! he!" gave me a push that might have caused me a close acquaintance with the floor, had I not saved myself by grasping the lady's arm.  But the force was such that I could not prevent a more awkward catastrophe and I came plump into her lap.  The laughter occasioned by the accident restored the bridegroom's good humor, - which at first had vanished, and a storm appeared brewing - and he remarked: 
"Well, Mr Piper, I'll excuse ye this time, but yer mustn't be comin' yer city fashions too strong here agin', or ye may have wuss handling?.  The fellers have a right to kiss the gals just as much as they please; but after they is married, none but their old man has a right."
I apologized, and retired to make room for other visitors who were pressing forward to gain audience.  Not feeling disposed to again attempt a passage through the dancers, I took up my position near the fireplace, leaning my elbow up on the mantel and my head upon my hand, in rather a pensive mood.  There was not more than a cord of wood blazing away upon the hearth, but my position soon became uncomfortable - the perspiration began to start from my forehead, and run down my face in a perfect deluge; but there was no opportunity for for im-

interesting part of the evening's entertainment; the bride looked so bewitchingly charming in her maiden modesty, which vanished so exquisitely with the affirmative nod, and the bridegroom said, "I will," with such a bold and decided air, - as much as to say, "who's affraid," and meant what he said, and then he gave his newly acquired wife such a hearty smack upon its conclusion as to infect the whole company with spontaneous come unclear, and cause such a deafening volley of percussive explosions of the true unclear stamp.
After being used as a shuttlecock by the unclear, and rebounding from sir to miss, while each roared with laughter, as he or she gave new impulse by a hearty propulsion to my side - long movement, I at length arrived before the mistress of ceremony, who was seated in a corner near the chimney.  I made my best bow, and paid my best compliments to herself and the happy pair, who were reclining on a "sofy" near their mama, trilling and cooing like a pair of turtle doves only with a "leetle" more warmth and energy.  I interrupted their happiness by the usual congratulations and a kiss; but I dwelt too long on the latter subject to please the bridegroom, who, laying his rough hand on my shoulder remarked:  "I say, Mr. Piper" - I told them my name

21
and when indulged was of the most silly description.
"Very pleasant weather we have, sir."
"Why, yes, sir, if not more."
"Bad for the steam boats on the lake this fog?."
"Considerable - provided they take the precaution to run into each other."
"What a dunce", I said mentally, as I turned away.  "I'll engage this young lady in the corner.  Do you enjoy dancing, Miss?"
"Why, he! he! he!  I really don't know - as I can say - as I don't; he! he! but I do love blind-man's-buff."
"It is quite an exciting game, is it not?"
"Well, I can't say as I ever got excited by it.  I shouldn't think it more'n licker."
("Humph! I'll change the subject.) Do you ever engage in literary pursuits?"
"I don't know as I ever pursued any thing, sir; and I am sure - he! he! - that I never - he! he! was engaged - he! he!"
"Oh! I meant to inquire whether you read much, Miss?"
"Oh! yes, I am considered quite a lover of books."
"Have you seen Cooper's last?"
"The cooper's last!  Why I thought it was shoemakers that used lasts.  Do coopers use them too?"

20
mediate escape; every avenue save that through the dancers was completely jamed up, and of two evils I chose rather to remain and slowly evaporate, than to run the hazard of having my neck broken by the mischievous romps?.  There I stood, therefore, until, being quite roasted on one side, I was beginning to think of turning round and roasting the "goose on the other", when the dancing ceased, and gave me an opportunity of retiring into the back room, less densely populated, and where cake, whiskey toddy, "apple-sauce, and other refreshments for both "man and beast" were served up.
An old piano, too, occupied one corner of the room, which, when not giving forth the lively notes of the dance, was used by some sentimental miss to accompany a voice with that peculiar nasal twang so perfectly indescribable, while it sang -
"On the banks where drooped the willow,"
or,
Oh! 'tis love, 'tis love, that rules us all completely," or some other love ditty of like character.
After, the company had become tired of "tripping upon the light fantastic toe," hunt the slipper - button, button, who'se got the button? - forfeits, and such like games were resorted to, to pass away the time; but as to conversation, that was a thing of very little importance,

23
against my inclinations, I consented.  A large basket was brought in and placed in the middle of the room, upside down.  One of the most beautiful of the young ladies took a seat upon it, and all the young men, including myself, joined hands and moved around her, while she unclear the supposed qualities of each as he passed.  As I came before her she pronounced the words, "and him I elect to be my knight true; wilt thou my bidding do?"
Of course I could not refuse so charming a creature, and being perfectly ignorant of the nature of the play and their designs against me, I answered:
"Most lovely fair one, it is for you to command, me to obey.  What thou orderest, that I will do."
I was then directed to get into the basket, which had been turned over for the purpose; of course I obeyed.  I was covered over with the fair one's shawl, and presently I found myself lifted upon the shoulders of two of the lads, and borne three times around the room, while the young ladies chanted some kind of a hocus-pocus, the words of which I neither heard nor understood.  Soon I found myself going up a flight of stairs, while the voices gradually became fainter and fainter, and at last ceased altogether.  I ventured to poke my head out

22
"I had reference to Mr. Cooper's new novel, Miss."
"Oh! had you? No, I never read such trash.  I like history best."
"Pray, who is your favorite author, Miss?"
"What a funny questioner you are, he! he! he!  Why, the author of my being, to be sure."
"Excuse me, Miss, for not being sufficiently comprehensive; I wished to ask what histories you like best."
"Robinson Crusoe, Baron Trenk, Baron Munchausen, Children of the Abbey, Paul and Virginia and Gulliver's Travels."
"What a charming taste you have, Miss," and I bowed myself away to seek other sources of enjoyment.
Hitherto I had amused myself with the verdantry? and ignorance of my country friends, but now "a change came o'er the spirit of my" - unclear.  While I chuckled at their unsophisticatedness they were preparing to induct me into some of the mysteries of country life.  A few of the most intelligent youngsters had noticed the evident satisfaction with which I looked upon all their attempts at refinement, and were resolved to be revenged.
I was requested to take part in a new play - a very funny one, they said - and not wishing to give offense, although somewhat

25
from the direction taken after leaving the parlors, I imagined myself in the garret of the house.  The basket was placed on the floor, some mummery gone through, each placed his hands upon my head, the basket was recovered, again mounted on their shoulders, and I was taken back to the place from whence I came.
"When we clap our hands three times," said someone, "you must appear suddenly from the basket, and claim your lady love."
All fears of a practical joke had now vanished from my mind, and I was vain enough to suppose that some pleasing divertisement in my honor, as the stranger? guest, was to meet my eyes.  The ladies - that is the young ones - now chanted a verse, and the signal was given.  I sprang up, and leaning upon the edge of the basket, gave my face as comical an expression as possible, and gazed around the room.  A tremendous burst of laughter saluted me.  The b'hoys roared and held their sides, and the g'hals, with some compunctions?, giggled and stuffed their mouths full of handkerchiefs, while I could hear my fair cousins whisper: "It is too bad."
I wondered what it was "too bad," and looked about to ascertain the cause of so much mirth; but I could perceive nothing.  At

24
of the basket, but a heavy hand falling upon it rather forcibly, I drew it in again quickly.
Up, up we went, and I puzzled my brain, to no purpose, to solve the question as to my probably destination.  I called to mind that jovial old rogue, Jack Fallstaff, and began to fear that the romps of K--- were about to give me the same treatment he received from the "Merry Wives of Windsor", and I rather calculate if I didn't feel about the smallest of a man just at that moment, then "there ain't no snaiks?".
On we went, and they appeared to be putting in practice the physician's advice, "When taken, to be well shaken," for they rolled and tumbled me about in the basket as if I were a small measure of potatoes.  With each oscilation I could hear the rogues chuckle.  I again ventured my head above the basket and exclaimed, "What the devil are you about!" but the same heavy hand obliged me to disappear as suddenly as the ghost of Hamlet's father, at the Olympic, and a voice of the "beware!" intonation bade me be quiet until I was let out.  This calmed my fears somewhat, for I concluded that if I was to be let out, I should not be thrown out, forgetting that with the Wolverines, to let out, to heave out, and to throw out, signified precisely the same thing.

At this time the "Great Land speculation feore" raged at its heighth through. out the West. Villages, towns and cities opnange milo existence no the cause of a night_ beauti-ful facues were laid waste and "staked out" and sold when bred and mortgage at very cheap rates, and many wild schemes were in-vented for getting rich rapidly.
The little village of R__ had no sooner recovered from the excitement of the wedding than it was agitated by the appearance of a very richly dressed young man, who, with a cane no one haud and a quizzing glaze be-tween the thunnel and firefueger of the other, sauntered through the town with the air of a prince, causing the little hearts of all the young ladies to palpitate and flutter with excessive augiety lest so pretty, agreable and furinuling a gentleman should depart without breaking one or more of their afore said little hearts. Mr. G__ was a tall, well proportioned individual and prided himself upon the elegance of his dress, and his exceedingly gentlemanly  department. He was descended from an eminent and honorable family residing in the State of New York, but unfortunately had more money in his jacket than brains in his head.

length my favorite cousin Ann came up to me and said: "They have been playing a trick upon you.  Come, let us go home.  It is shameful, and I'll never set foot within these doors again."  Her little face was crimson with anger.
I rushed to the mirror.  I could not believe my eyes.  My hair was completely covered with flour, and my face with soot.  "Ah, ha!  that's your game, is it," thinks I.  "Let them laugh who win."  I turned from the mirror, walked deliberately up to my fair judge, and, before she could avoid me, covered her with kisses, leaving at every buss a beauty spot upon her rosey lips and cheeks.  A fair proportion of soot and flour was also deposited upon the white satin and silk vests of my late couriers and well washed in with whiskey punch.  The tables were turned.  The rogues were furious, the girls uproarious; and while the former rushed from the house with vows of vengeance upon their lips, I strutted, with begrimed face and powdered hair, through the rooms, laughing as heartily at my own odd appearance as any of them, until the hour of adjournment arrived, when I took my departure with the rest, after again kissing the bride, leaving my mark upon her and wish her a sleepless night.  Moral - You disarm ridicule, aimed at yourself, by joining in it.
